nodes.text: The common use of constant elasticity of substitution (CES) functions in integrated assessment models causes an artifactually monotonically increasing carbon price and misrepresents long-term technological energy transitions

Integrated assessment models (IAMs) are widely used to link climate and economy and to derive carbon prices but they exhibit common structural assumptions and criticisms (discount rates, damage functions, handling of catastrophes)
Many prominent IAMs use CES or nested CES variants to model production and technological substitution across sectors
CES functions are share-preserving and imply that replacing a dominant input requires exponentially increasing amounts of the substitute as substitution progresses

Mathematically, CES yields a marginal rate of technical substitution dependent on the ratio of factor shares, producing decreasing marginal substitution ease and declining elasticity as penetration of the substitute is modeled

A stylized CES substitution example replacing fossil energy with renewables shows that large reductions in fossil share require exponentially large increases in renewables and produce exponentially rising carbon taxes

Empirical IAM implementations using CES or nested CES include models such as GTEM-C, EPPA, GCAM, MERGE and variants where results show very high future carbon prices and limited direct renewable penetration without backstop technologies
The CES-driven example and derivation produce carbon price trajectories that start low and rise exponentially, sometimes to thousands of dollars per ton, even for partial substitution scenarios
Observed outputs from multiple IAMs mirror this artifact: models report carbon price knees late in the century and reliance on CCS, nuclear, or biomass as dominant mitigation options

This CES artifact is policy-relevant because it causes price diversion (focus on price setting over physical planning), sticker shock (perceived prohibitive costs), and technological myopia (favoring technologies already in model shares)
Historical technological and energy transitions follow S-curve diffusion patterns with dynamic, increasing ease of substitution at early and middle stages and associated learning and cost declines
Because CES cannot represent S-curve dynamics where elasticity evolves, its use leads to systematic overestimation of transition costs and unrealistic carbon price trajectories

A practical modification is to use a dynamically varying elasticity of substitution calibrated to expected technology diffusion, which produces more realistic substitution and carbon price patterns in illustrative models
Simulation demonstrations with linearly or exponentially decreasing elasticity recreate S-curve like substitution behavior and remove the unrealistically exponential carbon price rise

Recommendation: move toward physics-driven energy models and policy approaches that set deployment and phase-out targets for renewables and storage rather than relying primarily on CES-based price pathways
